title: Conclusion for test of mean teacher hours worked

content.description: A state study on labor reported that one-third of full-time teachers in the state also worked part time at another job. For those teachers, the average number of hours worked per week at the part-time job was <math alttext="13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. After an increase in state teacher salaries, a random sample of <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> teachers who worked part time at another job was selected. The average number of hours worked per week at the part-time job for the teachers in the sample was <math alttext="12.5" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>12.5</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> with standard deviation <math alttext="6.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours.
content.question: Is there convincing statistical evidence, at the level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>Î±</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.05</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, that the average number of hours worked per week at part-time jobs decreased after the salary increase?

choices.label: No. The <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of the appropriate test is greater than <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No. The <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of the appropriate test is less than <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes. The <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of the appropriate test is greater than <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes. The <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></math>-value of the appropriate test is less than <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Not enough information is given to determine whether there is convincing statistical evidence.

content.answer: No. The <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of the appropriate test is greater than <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 7.5: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 4.E: Justify a claim using a decision based on significance tests.
